Comment: But where do we draw the line? Is it up to the president to decide who is and isn't a terrorist?   Remember January 6? When thousands of people stormed the Capitol building. The DOJ purposefully avoided charging defendents with terrorism charges because of the implications it could have on future cases. They worried that charging them as terrorists could lower the bar for what constitutes "terrorism."  There are exactly 57 items that constitute terrorism in the eyes of the judicial system. Such as: hijacking a plane, using fire or explosives to destroy a building. Producing a smallpox virus is also on the list, too.   By loosening the definition of "terrorism," we are opening the door to allow anyone sitting in the Oval Office to label a group of people they don't like as terrorists. I know you said that we're worrying about things that haven't happened yet. I understand that this seems far-fetched. But these safeguards exist for a reason, and it is vital to a functioning democracy that we maintain the rule of law.
